articles.author: 3DiVi Inc.
articles.description:
Since 1999, Canadian photographer Fran√ßois Brunelle has been chasing a fascinating mystery: Can two complete strangers look like identical twins?
His ongoing photo project ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Not a Look-A-like!‚Äù features striking black-and-white portraits of unrelated people who resemble each other so much, they could easily pass as twins. Over the years, Brunelle has photographed more than 250 such pairs in 32 cities around the world.
But how does facial recognition technology see these ‚Äútwins‚Äù? We decided to find out.
We ran several of Brunelle‚Äôs look-alike portraits through our online facial recognition demo.
The result? The algorithm didn‚Äôt find a single match‚Äîeven in cases where most people would swear it was the same person.
Let‚Äôs take a closer look at how the experiment worked ‚Äî starting with how ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Do We All Have a Lookalike? Face Recognition vs. Human Eye

articles.author: LawsonPeters
articles.description:
Photo Credit: Unsplash / FLY:D
Your personal data has real monetary value on the black market.
Data brokers and cybercriminals both collect and sell your information.
Identity theft is easier than you think - even your phone number and address can be weaponized.
Regulations like GDPR, CCPA, and NDPR exist - but your data is still at risk.
Learn how to protect your digital footprint with simple, actionable tips.
We‚Äôve all heard the saying, ‚ÄúIf you're not paying for the product, you are the product.‚Äù
From that ‚Äúfree‚Äù weather app to your Facebook likes, data is being harvested every second. But who profits from your digital life?
The answer: Data brokers, advertisers and yes-cybercriminals(opsüåö).
In 2023, a hacker leaked 10 million customers‚Äô personal data from a popular fitness app. Emails,‚Ä¶
articles.title: Why Hackers Want Your Personal Data (And How They Use It)

articles.author: Shruti Saraswat
articles.description:
Translating over 50 hours of video content wasn‚Äôt something I planned to do all at once. It started with one lecture, then a course module, then product tutorials‚Äîuntil it became clear I needed something faster, scalable, and accurate enough to handle multilingual audiences without sacrificing quality.
In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through what actually works (and what doesn‚Äôt) when you‚Äôre trying to localize video content with AI voice dubbing, including real-world insights from my experience working with hours of audio, multiple speakers, and content ranging from YouTube explainers to internal training material.
Whether you're a dev building tools for video processing, a creator localizing your content, or a team handling educational or marketing media, these lessons might save you a ton of‚Ä¶
articles.title: What I Learned Translating 50+ Hours of Video Content with AI Voice Dubbing

articles.author: AK
articles.description:
Python's most commonly used built-in functions, organized by alphabet. Each function is explained with a brief description, an example, and some fun üéâ emojis to make it easier and more enjoyable to learn.
abs() ‚Äì Absolute value



Returns the absolute value of a number
abs(-7)  # 7

all() ‚Äì Checks if all items are True



Returns True if all elements in an iterable are true
all([1, 2, 3])  # True

any() ‚Äì Any item True?



Returns True if at least one element is True
any([False, 0, 5])  # True

ascii() ‚Äì String representation



Returns a string containing a printable representation
ascii("caf√©")  # "'caf\\xe9'"

bin() ‚Äì Binary representation



Returns binary version of a number
bin(5)  # '0b101'

bool() ‚Äì Boolean value



Converts a value to Boolean (True or False)
bool(0)  # False

byt‚Ä¶
articles.title: üêç Python Built-in Functions - Ultimate Cheat Sheet

articles.author: Thadeus Ogondola
articles.description:
The world of containers is at a crossroads. Docker, the platform that started it all, still reigns supreme with over 20 million developers. But Podman, with its security-first, daemonless architecture, is rapidly gaining ground, especially in enterprise and security-conscious environments.
So, which one is right for you in 2024-2025? It's not about which is "better," but which one fits your needs. Let's break down the core technical differences.
Architecture: Daemon vs. Daemonless


The biggest difference between Docker and Podman lies in their fundamental architecture.
Docker uses a client-server model with a persistent, root-privileged daemon (dockerd) that manages all containers. This central daemon is a single point of control and a potential point of failure. All container processes a‚Ä¶
articles.title: Podman vs Docker: The 2024-2025 Technical Showdown

articles.author: Peter Davis
articles.description:
Part 3 of 3 in Git Tales Series

"Some files vanish from sight, but not from memory. Git remembers. So do attackers." 
We‚Äôve journeyed deep into the underbelly of modern software development where secrets hide in plain sight, tucked between commits and CI scripts, waiting to be exhumed. In Part 1, we met the careless developer. In Part 2, we followed the breadcrumbs into service accounts, dangling credentials, and quiet privilege escalation in the cloud.
Now, this is the final part of the Git Tales trilogy ‚Äî and unlike the previous tales, this one breaks apart into three standalone compromises, each unearthed through separate hunts, reported via three different bug bounty programs, and rewarded with high to critical payouts.
Each started differently. Each felt like an accident ‚Äî a digital ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Final Tale: Part 3 - The Gateways We Left Open

articles.author: Fazly Fathhy
articles.description:
Kubernetes (K8s) has become the de facto standard for container orchestration, but setting it up and managing its control plane can be complex and time-consuming. This is where Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) comes in‚Äîa fully managed Kubernetes service offered by AWS that simplifies cluster management while providing scalability, security, and high availability out of the box.
üîß What is EKS?

Amazon EKS is AWS's managed Kubernetes service. It helps you run Kubernetes without needing to install and operate your own control plane or manage master nodes. AWS handles the heavy lifting, so you can focus on deploying and scaling your applications.
Key Features of EKS:
AWS-managed Control Plane:
Master Node Management:
Control Plane Components Installed by AWS:
API Server ‚Äì Handles communication between the Kubernetes components and user commands.


Scheduler ‚Äì Assigns workloads to specific nodes based on resource availability and requirements.


Controller Manager ‚Äì Governs the cluster state, ensuring the desired number of pods and other resources.


etcd ‚Äì The key-value store that acts as Kubernetes‚Äô backing store for all cluster data.




ü§î Why Use EKS?
Fully managed: Focus on your workloads rather than infrastructure.
Highly available and secure: AWS distributes the control plane across multiple Availability Zones (AZs).
Integrated wthe AWS AWS ecosystem: Leverage IAM, VPC, CloudWatch, and other services easily.
Scalable: Handle production workloads with ease, whether small-scale or enterprise-level.
Certified Kubernetes: Easily migrate applications to/from other Kubernetes environments.
‚öôÔ∏è Worker Nodes in EKS
While AWS manages the control plane, you have options when it comes to managing worker nodes‚Äîthe nodes that run your actual container workloads.

Self-managed Nodes


Managed Node Groups


AWS Fargate
articles.title: üöÄ Introduction to Amazon EKS ‚Äì AWS Managed Kubernetes Service

articles.author: Mehak.
articles.description:
Recently, I became curious about how GitHub webhooks work. To deepen my understanding, I built a small Node.js project that sends an email notification every time a pull request (PR) is opened.
Yes, GitHub already has a built-in notification system, but building your own gives you full control and a deeper understanding of the ecosystem.
Before we dive into code, it‚Äôs important to understand how GitHub ensures that webhook events are secure.
HMAC stands for Hash-based Message Authentication Code. It‚Äôs a cryptographic technique used to verify both:
The integrity of a message (that it hasn‚Äôt been tampered with)
The authenticity of the sender (that it‚Äôs really from GitHub)
GitHub does this by hashing the body of the request with a shared secret you provide when creating the webhook. It then s‚Ä¶
articles.title: üì¨ Understanding GitHub Webhooks: Send Email Notifications on Pull Request Events Using Node.js
